issues.description: Method name mismatch for the supply-delivery API: the problem statement (UML and task text) requires a static method named acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int), but the solution implements a static method named receiveDelivery(String, int, int). This discrepancy will confuse students about which method to implement and will cause automated tests (and student implementations that follow the spec) to fail or not match the reference implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent. Either (A) rename the solution's receiveDelivery(...) method to acceptSupplyDelivery(...) (keeping the same parameters and behavior), or (B) update the problem statement and tests to require/expect receiveDelivery(...) instead of acceptSupplyDelivery(...). Prefer option (A) to match the problem text and UML.

issues.description: Contradictory guidance about initializing the stock field: the task text asks students to initialize both 'orders' and the 'final Stock stock' in the SealSaloon constructor (no-arg constructor), but elsewhere the task explicitly requires the stock attribute to be static (and final). Initializing a static final field in an instance constructor is incorrect in Java and will confuse students (and may lead to compile errors if they try).
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the wording in the problem statement: state that 'orders' should be initialized in the no-arg constructor, while the shared stock must be declared static final and initialized at declaration or in a static initializer (not in the instance constructor). For example, document that stock is 'private static final Stock stock = new Stock();' and that orders should be set to an empty Meal[] inside the SealSaloon constructor.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) requires a static method named acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int) to handle incoming ingredient deliveries, but the solution implements this functionality under the different identifier receiveDelivery(String, int, int). This naming mismatch means students reading the problem will look for acceptSupplyDelivery while the reference implementation (and likely tests) uses a different name, causing confusion mapping the requirement to the implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the identifier names. Rename the solution method receiveDelivery(...) to acceptSupplyDelivery(...), or add a static acceptSupplyDelivery(...) wrapper that delegates to receiveDelivery(...). This preserves the problem's required API and removes the mapping confusion for students.
